EXIT   X

COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT MEASURES

Page

Table of Contents

 

Examples of prohibition notices

 

The nature of a prohibition notice depends on the circumstances of each case. Prohibition notices that have previously been issued include notices:

 

•

requiring an employer to cease operating a gas storage area until a competent person carried out a risk assessment and took control measures

•

to stop processes involving the decanting of oil in a food-processing kitchen until a safe work procedure was issued that covers the cleaning of the fryers

•

to cease work at a site until adequate safety measures were implemented in order to prevent falls

 

An inspector may issue a prohibition notice if he or she believes that, because of an exposure to an immediate or imminent hazard at the workplace:

 

•

an activity's occurrence poses a serious risk to a person's health and safety

•

a certain activity's occurrence will involve a serious risk to a person's health and safety

 

A prohibition notice will prohibit the activity (or carrying on of the activity in a specified way) until the inspector is satisfied that the risk has been remedied. For example, a notice may prohibit the use of certain machinery until appropriate guarding is affixed.

 

If a person fails to comply with a notice, the regulator may take remedial action. The regulator must inform the person of what the remedial action may be, and their liability for its cost.

 

The regulator can also apply to the court for an enforceable injunction, which can compel a person to comply with, or restrain them from contravening any notice they have been issued.

BE CAREFUL

 

Failing to comply with a prohibition notice can result in fines of up to $100,000 for individuals, and $500,000 for corporations.

 

(Victoria: $75,835)

 

(Victoria: $379,175)
